post.author: WebMD Morgan
post.post_content:
As if there weren't enough things to worry about.

Now Gonorrhea appears to be developing resistance to the last two effective antibiotics available to treat it in the United States. Several patients undergoing treatment for Gonorrhea displayed an increased resistance to azithryomazin, an antibiotic used to treat Gonorrhea, and ceftriaxone, the antibiotic given alongside azithromycin in the dual regimen recommended by the CDC.

Do you think that this will cause people to take curable STDs like Gonorrhea more seriously?

Click here to read more about drug-resistant Gonorrhea and about the new drug that might be effective in treating sexually transmitted diseases: http://wb.md/2cZseWy

Note to Readers: If you want to join the conversation, sign in (or sign up to be a WebMD member). See the link in the upper right corner of this page. Thanks!

post.post_title: Can asymptomatic HSV-1 turn symptomatic through exposure?
post.post_content:
New boyfriend gets cold sores, AKA HSV-1. He's very careful to let me know when he feels one coming on, and won't kiss me until it's completely gone. I appreciate his concern, but have been reading a lot about this condition and have a question.
Sounds like at least 70% of people have this virus. Given my past, I'd say it's likely I am in this 70%. But, I've never had a cold sore. If I DO have the virus, does that mean that kissing him when he has a cold sore won't actually do any damage? Or is there a possibility that I will start getting cold sores after kissing him, even if I already have the virus? I know that if I do already have it, I could start getting cold sores at any time, but for now (first 30 years of my life), I seem to be asymptomatic.
I want to make sure that I'm being careful, but am also not setting up boundaries that don't need to be there.

responses.author: WebMD Morgan
responses.resp_title: RE: Bleeding during sex?
responses.resp_content:
Hi there and thanks for posting,

I'm sorry to hear of your breakthrough bleeding but I'm happy to hear that you're at least not experiencing any discomfort. There might be some truth to what gagrrl said about breakthrough bleeding while on the pill. Spotting or breakthrough bleeding is especially apparent within the first couple of months of taking birth control or sometimes if you're not taking it at the same time everyday. I would definitely suggest talking to your OB-GYN about this possibility.

Here ( http://wb.md/2cg9Qf3) are some of the reasons for abnormal vaginal bleeding (information about breakthrough bleeding caused by birth control is included here too). It might be helpful to use this resource to prepare you for your next visit with your OB-GYN.

Please keep us posted! We care about you and we're here for you ((hugs)).

post.author: Anonymous
post.post_title: I live with someone that has oral/eye herpes. Can I get eye herpes from touching faucet and then using finger to get eye booger out of my inner eye immediately after?
post.post_content:
Let's say the faucet handle was wet and this person that has active sores used the faucet one hour prior. I come along to wash my hands with soap and water in a sink [that also has dirty dishes in it] and water on the faucet handle and then I turn off the faucet. Immediately after, while at the sink, I use a finger to extract an eye booger from the inner corner of my eye. Can I get eye herpes from this given the time frame and circumstance (wet faucet handle/soiled dishes that might have splattered)? The person I live with has oral and eye herpes. His first episode was after visiting a dentist many years ago and was confirmed as herpes by a doctor. He has a bad immune system and is older so he often has breakouts and generally always has some kinds of sores on his face.

I've read multiple things about how long it can live outside of the body and cause transmission. One is that herpes cannot live on dead surfaces for more than 10 seconds, but I've also read it can live on non porous solid objects for 4-8 hours (like a faucet) and wet cloth for 2-4 hours and dry cloth for 15 minutes. Not sure what to go by and what my risk is considering it was a wet solid object and I immediately stuck my finger in my eye but it was an hour after the sink was last used.

I don't want to make him feel bad about it so I don't bring it up but I'm crashing here for a little bit and when things like this occur I worry about transmission. It's not usually the first thing on my mind though so I do things like shut off the faucet and then rub my eyes thinking, 'oh, i just washed my hands so they're clean and I can clean my eyes,' and then start to worry ten minutes later realizing I didn't do the most sanitary thing and could have exposed myself to it.

responses.author: Anonymous
responses.resp_title: RE: I live with someone that has oral/eye herpes. Can I get eye herpes from touching faucet and then using finger to get eye booger out of my inner eye immediately after?
responses.resp_content: (I'm the OP) I should note, I do not have hsv 1 or hsv 2 so I don't have antibodies.

responses.author: WebMD Morgan
responses.resp_title: RE: I live with someone that has oral/eye herpes. Can I get eye herpes from touching faucet and then using finger to get eye booger out of my inner eye immediately after?
responses.resp_content:
Hi there,

It says here ( http://wb.md/2coUi7v ) HSV-1 and HSV-2 are transmitted through direct contact, including kissing, sexual contact (vaginal, oral, or anal sex), or skin-to-skin contact. This article does say that HSV-1 can be spread by sharing things such as towels, eating utensils, and razors but does not specify the length of time after an infected person uses it that the infection risk is still high (http://wb.md/2bYdM6n).


More information on the transmission of herpes: http://wb.md/2bTkhBh .

If you are concerned about contracting herpes, I it may be a good idea to speak with your doctor. Your doctor will be able to tell you how herpes is spread and what you can do to protect yourself!

Good luck and keep us posted :)
